dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear about your time living in a commune.

dialogue_content.original_text: I was in my late twenties, full of energy and idealism.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: The commune was located in the countryside, surrounded by rolling hills and endless fields.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like a vibrant time. What brought you to join the commune in the first place?

dialogue_content.original_text: I had just finished art school and was feeling a bit disillusioned with the traditional career path.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember arriving with just a backpack and my potter’s wheel, ready to embrace this new lifestyle.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been quite a shift from art school. How did living in the commune influence your pottery?

dialogue_content.original_text: I started creating pieces that reflected our collective ideals—things like pottery that was practical for our shared meals.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Things really shifted when the gallery that exhibited our art caught fire.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been hard. How did you and the community cope with the aftermath of the fire?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: It was incredibly challenging for all of us. For me, it was particularly tough because my pottery was my main source of income. I poured my grief into my work, creating pieces that were more raw and emotional.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: And how did this aftermath impact your personal journey, especially your work with pottery?

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember one series I created was entirely inspired by the concept of the phoenix rising from the ashes.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: And when did you start noticing changes in your hands?

dialogue_content.original_text: I was in my late fifties when I first noticed something wasn't quite right.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been really challenging. How did you adapt to the changes brought on by arthritis?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Oh, it was quite an adjustment, to be honest. But I decided I wasn't ready to give it up without a fight. I started experimenting with different techniques that required less strain on my hands, like hand-building instead of using the wheel. I also began teaching pottery classes.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: And how do you feel looking back at everything now?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Reflecting on my journey, I feel a deep sense of gratitude. Each experience has shaped me into who I am today. I'm proud of how I've navigated these hurdles.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: Before we finish, Fiona, I'd love to ask, what lesson or wisdom would you like to share with others from your life experiences?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: I suppose if there's one thing I've learned, it's the importance of resilience and adaptability. Embrace change, even when it's difficult. Keep your heart open, and you'll always find a way forward.
